profile.name: Kazuki Kanda
profile.tagline: Site Reliability Engineer / Machine Learning Engineer
summary: Site Reliability Engineer and Machine Learning Engineer building and operating services in Ruby, Rust, and Python.
Works with AWS and Terraform (with some Azure exposure) to keep systems predictable while enabling ML-driven features.
Interested in the interface between high-level abstraction and low-level systems; prefers quiet precision over hype.

ui.timelineNote: Add organizations, scope, and scale when available.

focus: Exploring VM/runtime/GC behavior to bridge ML workloads with system constraints.
Learning about OS behavior, memory layout, and boundary cases that surface edge conditions.
Designing review flows that align responsibility, data flow clarity, and failure isolation.
Building workflows that keep ML deployments observable and reproducible.
Maintaining safety rails around infrastructure change management (AWS, Terraform, Azure exposure).

projects.name: PracCode
projects.oneLiner: Code-reading training platform for web engineers (2-5 years) to practice responsible implementation reviews.
highlights: Flow: choose problem -> read code -> write answer -> AI evaluation -> review responsibility, data flow, and error handling.
AI evaluation powered by LLMs (Ollama/Gemini) to surface gaps and reinforce learning loops.
Built with Next.js, Fastify, Prisma, PostgreSQL, and NextAuth to deliver a responsive web experience.
projects.tech: Next.js, Fastify, Prisma, PostgreSQL, NextAuth, LLM (Ollama/Gemini)

projects.name: llm-control
projects.oneLiner: TypeScript SDK for token rate and concurrency control in LLM API calls, treating errors as congestion signals.
highlights: Token rate limiter uses token bucket with AIMD to adapt tokens per second while allowing bursts.
Concurrency limiter adjusts the inflight window with AIMD and respects Retry-After for 429/503/timeout signals.
Includes EWMA cost estimation and Prometheus-compatible telemetry with provider-agnostic abstractions.
